name: Wastewater treatment; Conventional plug flow activated sludge, Level 1; at plant
description:
This gate-to gate process reflects treatment of 1 cubic meter of wastewater, to the following specification:

Influent wastewater quality: Suspended solids - 220 mg/L, Biological oxygen demand - 220 mg/L, Total nitrogen - 40 mg/L N, Total phosphorus - 5 mg/L. 

Level 1 Effluent quality: Suspended solids - 20 mg/L, Biological oxygen demand - 7.7 mg/L, Total nitrogen - 30 mg/L, Total phosphorus - 4.9 mg/L

Inventory data was generated for a theortical process configuration treating on average 10 million gallons per day of wastewater. Key information is available in process metadata. Full process documentation is available in EPA report number 832-R-21-006A.

System boundaries of the treatment process include energy, chemical, consumable inputs and greenhouse gas emissions for major primary, secondary, tertiary, disinfection and solids treatment processes. Release of treated effluent to surface water and landfill disposal of generated sludge are modeled in separate (linked) processes. Basic infrastructure is also included (excavation, concrete, steel). Operation of the sewage collection system, infrastructure disposal, and electrical and mechanical equipment (e.g. pumps body, control boxes, clarifier scraper arm) are outside of the system boundaries. 

Wastewater treatment processes are available for five levels of treatment performance. Level one is the lowest standard. Level five produces the cleanest effluent.
category: 22: Utilities/2213: Water, Sewage and Other Systems

processDocumentation.timeDescription: Wastewater effluent quality standards will change over time and with geography. Current and future wastewater standards should be reflected in treatment levels establish for the level 1 through level 5 systems. Updating background electricity and input data should maintain process relevance so long as the target treatment system matches the defined system.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription:
conventional plug flow activated sludge, Level 1: Treatment processes include: grit removal, clarifiers, activated sludge biological process, chlorination/dechlorination, gravity thickening, anaerobic digestion and centrifugation.

Level 1 Effluent quality- Suspended solids - 20 mg/L, Biological oxygen demand - 7.7 mg/L, Total nitrogen - 30 mg/L, Total phosphorus - 4.9 mg/L"
processDocumentation.modelingConstantsDescription: Inventory data was generated for a theortical process configuration treating on average 10 million gallons per day of wastewater. The CAPDET Works software package (maintained by Hydromantis) is the primary source of inventory data for process energy use, chemicals, infrastructure materials, sludge hauling and biogas production. Process greenhouse gas emissions were estimated using calculations from the IPCC greenhouse gas inventory guidelines.
processDocumentation.completenessDescription: Exclusion of mechanical and electrical equipment from the system boundary is the only known missing, non-trivial inventory item. CAPDET works balances mass to model effluent quality and sludge quantity. However, across the entire process a mass balance was not calculated.
processDocumentation.dataSelectionDescription: All outputs of the CAPDET model that could be used to develop LCI data were included in the model. Additional data on process greenhouse gas emissions and biogas processing were developed from literature sources to supplement gaps in the inventory
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: Outputs of the CAPDET model are reported on an annual (energy, chemicals) or lifetime (infrastructure) basis. Annual quantities are standardized to the functional unit by dividing by the average quantity of wastewater treated per year. For inventory data reported on a lifetime basis, quantities are standardized to the functional unit by amortizing the inventory item over the expected lifespan of the infrastructure component.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: System boundaries of the treatment process include all major primary, secondary, tertiary, disinfection and solids treatment processes. Release of treated effluent to surface water and landfill disposal of generated sludge are modeled in separate (linked) processes. Basic infrastructure is included (excavation, concrete, steel). Operation of the sewage collection system, infrastructure disposal, and electrical and mechanical equipment are outside of the system boundaries. Inventory data was derived from model runs in CAPDET Works and supplemented with values developed using basic engineering calculations and values derived from literature. Uncertainty data is not included for this process.
processDocumentation.useAdvice:
This process reflects wastewater treatment using Conventional plug flow activated sludge, Level 1 wastewater treatment technology. Impacts associated with effluent release and sludge disposal in a landfill are modeled in separate (linked) processes. Used in isolation this process will not reflect the full scope (gate-to-grave) of wastewater treatment impacts. 

It is recommended that users update the electricity mix to reflect their region and a data year corresponding to the scope of their analysis. 

Wastewater treatment processes are available for five levels of treatment performance. Level one refers to the lowest nutrient standard. Level five produces the cleanest effluent. If possible, select the level of wastewater treatment based on permit standards for the target wastewater treatment plant and the type of biological process used. 

If comparing LCIA results against source: The linked background electricity dataset has significantly lower impacts than the grid in the original source. Additionally, significant changes in characterization factors occurred between USETox versions 1 and 2, which strongly influences toxicity results for this process.
processDocumentation.intendedApplication:
This process is intended to be used as a background process by LCA practitioners, industry and the general public to reflect the impact of wastewater treatment within their product systems. This process must be used in conjunction with the associated effluent and sludge landfilling processes to model the full scope of wastewater treatment impacts. The inventory should be sufficient to model TRACI 2.1 and USETox impact categories.

Situation C2 - Accounting, without system-external interatctions. The intended application is a purely descriptive accounting / documentation of the analysed system excluding existing interactions with other systems in the LCI model.
processDocumentation.projectDescription: Data were prepared by Eastern Research Group (ERG) on behalf of the U.S. EPA under Contract No. EP-C-14-022 WA 1-11, "LCA and Cost Assessment of Nutrient Removal Technologies"

dataGenerator.name: Franklin Associates, A Division of ERG
